div.head: A little Eye-Salve for the Kingdome and Armie, that they may see. VVherein is cleerly represented what the Supreme Power of the Kingdome is, and how it may be knowne. By a true Friend and Lover of those Powers and Magistrates that be of God.
div.p: THe Lord who is wonderfull in councell and excellent in working, who had according to his determinate will, as it were, withdrawne himselfe from the world, in the fore-going ages, hath now latey appeared againe in this Kingdome in some wonderfull workes of his, being, as it appears, about some notable designe for the advancement of the Kingdome of his deare Son.

We who have lived in any light of God, are not ignorant how that in this last age the supreme Magistrates of the Kingdome, had turned aside from the power of God, as well as from the way of God, and went about to strengthen themselves in their owne wayes, and to accomplish their owne designes by a multitude of evill doers, whom they every where encouraged, maintained, and preferred, that they might be serviceable to themselves in whatever their hearts should desire; and in this wicked way of their owne choosing, God in his secret and just judgement suffered them to prosper, till they had even almost oppressed all common justice, judgement and honesty in the State, and all spirituall worship and power of godlines in the Church. And then it became the fulnesse of time, for God to arise himselfe, and to stretch forth his owne arme, and for his own names sake to vindicate his own power in the State, and Christs in the Church: wherefore the Lord sounds an Alarum and gathers together a power
in the Kingdome, (not the first power, which was of mans choosing rather then Gods, and whom he cast off, as he cast off Saul; but the second power which was of his owne chusing and annointing, and whom he was with, as he was with David) and by this second power he breakes the Shield, the Sword and the Battell, he makes the Kings and Princes of the Army to fly, while the poore Countrey-people divide the spoile; and by this he utterly subdues the enemy in all his power of war. But this puts not an end to our evils, nor reduces us unto our former peace, as we were in good hope; but through the weake and wicked administrations of some, and the just judgement of God over all, the whole Kingdom is become one generall heap of confusion and disquiet, and no man now knowes which are those hills to which he should turne his eyes, or which are those mountaines from whence he should expect help, and the great question of all men at this time is, where now lies the supreme power.

In this matter, • crave leave of all my deare Countrimen, to speak freely my own apprehensions, not for the prejudice of any one man, much lesse of a whole Common-wealth, but for the profit and satisfaction of all.

The supreme power then in the Kingdome, is the power of God where ever it is to be found, and he cannot avoid the just censure of Atheisme who will deny, that the power of God is the supreme power, and that this supreme power of God ought to reigne in the world: for that remaines an unalterable truth, that it is the most high God that reignes in the Kingdomes of men; it is not men themselves that are to reigne in those Kingdomes they call their owne, nor the Devill that is to reigne by and through men, but it is the most high God that is to reigne, and the whole power of Government, both of this and all other Nations, is to be the power of God. Now the power of God reignes in the Kingdomes of men, sometimes under one forme, and sometimes under another; sometimes under Monarchy▪ sometimes under Aristocracy, sometimes under Democracy, &c. and it is no matter what the outward forme of Government be, so the power of God be underneath is: For it is not any forme of Government, that we are to stand by, and submit to, but the power of God in it;
but when the power of God leaves any forme of Government, we are not to stand by that forme, when it is destitute of the power of God, but we are to go along with the power of God, where ever that goes, and where that remaines we are to joyn, and there we are to submit our selves. This may be thus illustrated: The presence of God is, that which the Church is to joyne to, where ever it is to be found; now in the dayes of the Old Testament the presence of God for Worship was promised to the Temple, here will I dwell sai • h God, and therefore all the faithfull worshipped towards the Temple at Jerusalem, not for the Temples sake, but for Gods Presence sake which dwelt in the Temple: But now when Christ comes, the Presence of God leaves the Temple, to which it was annexed onely by a word, and dwells bodily in Christ: and therefore all the faithfull quite leaving the Temple, as the presence of God left it, now come to Christ, in whom the fulnesse of the Godhead dwells bodily, and the Temple is nothing at all to them; but the Jewes staying by the Temple when the presence of God had left it, became a reproach, curse, desolation and astonishment. So in like manner in point of Government, we may stay by any forme whilst the power of God is in it, but to stay by the forme, when the power of God is withdrawne, is to make our dwelling place with cruelty, tyranny, injustice, oppression and destruction.

Now the common people of the Kingdome, they onely regard the outward forme of Government, but the wiser people of the Nation they most minde the power of God in the forme: The ignorance of the former is the cause why they cry out so vehemently, Oh the King, the King, the King! and they say, they will never be quiet till they have the King againe, though he have quite cast off the power of God, and hath acted plainely and manifestly by a power as contrary to Gods, as darknesse is to light, and through that wicked power hath wasted Cities and Counties, and layed Townes and houses desolate, and slaine many thousands of men, women and children in England and Ireland, and hath drunk up our bloud as new wine, and fill'd both these Kingdomes with the sad outcries and lamentations of widdowes and orphans, and hath stuffed our borders full with mischiefs and miseries of all kinds; though I say, the King hath cast off Gods power, and to speake plainly, hath acted in the Devills, and though the power of God hath cast off him, and left him as a most remarkable piece of weakenesse in the midst of the Nation, and as a man truly without strength, yet they, a foolish people and unwise, cry out for this King againe, wherein they clearly say, give us a Governour that hath none
of the power of God at all with him, but who is acted by a contrary power, for the destruction of all the just waies of God among men. And truly, such a King may well serve such a people.

But those that are wise and rationall among us, they look above this regall forme: yea above all outward formes whatever, as well Parliamentary as Regall, and that power which they will onely own and acknowledge, it is the power of God among what sort of people soever it is to be found; for they know, that this is the only power of God that can and will govern men in justice, judgement and righteousnesse: and if Government be committed to any sort of men that are without this power, the consequence will certainely be tyranny and oppression, as we have seen in these dayes of ours in more then many instances.

To draw neare then to what I would say, if the King be destitute of the power of God, or the Parliament, or the like, they are no longer the supreme power, except we will resolvedly give up the Kingdomes of the world to the Devill, which not onely every Christian, but every man should contend against with all the power that God hath given him. But the power of God, though in a company of meane men, is absolutely the supreme power, to which all are to joyne themselves, and to which they are to submit: as we see in many instances of Scripture: for example, when the people of Israel were in Aegypt, they were all in an equall condition of bondage, and no one man above another, and who would have thought to have seen a King or Ruler amongst them, and then the presence and power of God found out Moses, and abode with him, and he became the Supreme power, and though at first the Israelite refused to obey, saying, Who made thee a Ruler and Judge over us? Yet when it was more manifest that the power of God was with him, then not he onely, but all the people obey'd him, and after when Moses died, how came Joshua above all the rest, to be the supreme power, but because God said to him, I will be with thee as I have been with Moses. Further, when God departed from Saul, (a King of the peoples preremptory choosing) the Supreme power was no longer with him; but God choosing David a poore Shepheard, the Supreme power, which is the power of God, became his, and the power of God with David, swallowed up by degrees the power of the creature which was with Saul, and so the Kingdome came to be established in Davids hands. After this, when David died, how came Solomon a younger brother to be the supreme power rather then Adonijah the first borne, but because God appeared to Solomon and was with him, and was not with Adonijah, &c. If any say, these were extraordinarie, and in the
first daies of the Church, I ansvver: No, it was Gods ordinarie way thus to deale, as you may see all along in the story of the Church, and God hath promised it shall be so also in the last daies of the Church, saying, Isa. 1. I will give them Judges as at the first, and Counsellours as at the beginning.
Now if any aske me, yea, but how shall wee know the power of God from other powers in the world, that we may come in unto that?

I answer, the Apostle gives us an unerring Character of such powers, Rom. 13. begin. where he saith, the Powers that be are ordained of God, and these Powers so ordained, do incourage and protect the good, and do terrify and revenge upon the evill, and in both these, they are the Ministers of God excercising his Power among men: & Peter saith, the Governours to which we are to submit, are sent of God, for the punishment of evill doers, and for the praise of them that do well. And thus it is evident, what that power is that is of God, and unto which wee are to submit.

Now if we look to the power that the King mannaged, it is notoriously knowne, that that power was a terror to the good, and a praise to the evill; that that power did punish the good, and reward the evill, and so was none of the power of God. How many good men in all parts of the Kingdome were vexed, oppressed, imprisoned, undone, banish'd, and driven into other parts of the world for succour, for their lives and livelihoods? and how many evill men, Popish and Antichristian Prelates, luxurious and tyrannicall Lords, unjust and wicked Judges, together with a multitude of prophane and ungodly persons of all conditions, did the King countenance, prefer, and put into places of trust and honour every where in the Kingdome? as if he had a project in his heart to strengthen himself against Jesus Christ, and totally to suppresse his Kingdome from having any place in his Dominions.

Now when it was thus apparent, that the Kings power was not Gods power, but contrary to it, God (according to his usuall dealing) raises up another power in the Kingdome and breakes that in pieces: and then the power came in the hands of the Parliament, and they at first laid hold on Gods power, and were mighty through it as long as they did cleave unto it: but now they not learning righteousnesse by Gods judgements on the Kings power, did also turne aside from Gods power to their own, and they became as unjust, tyrannicall and oppressive as the former power, and much more, and so how busie, cunning and active became they to suppresse godly men every where, and to encourage, protect and prefer evill men that might be serviceable to their owne turne, after the example of the King, till at last God powred contempt
upon them also, and raised up a sorry company of very servants and bondmen of the City, the actors and executioners of their Masters counsells, to invade the power of the Parliament, and to force them to make what Lawes they listed, which accordingly they did for feare of that rude multitude: God hereby declaring his departure from that forme also, and discovering that the power left behind would now be content to be subject even to the lusts of servants, and so would never be able againe to stand out against the new temptations and courtings of the King, if he should returne againe.

So that this present forme of the Parliament seemes to many men, as destitute of the power of God, as the former of the Kings; for I pray, what justice have they done, which concerned not themselves? What oppressed ones have they releeved that were not related to themselves? What ends have they prosecuted, but their owne? And so under this present power of theirs doth not the Kingdome groane under a thousand oppressions for one heretofore? Are not all our burdens multiplied? And is not injustice, cruelty, oppression, and most Arbitrary power, spread as a covering over the whole Kingdome, by the hands of their Committees? and are not they themselves still preparing more snares, for the most precious of the people of God, and preparing more opposition and resistance to Christs spirituall worship? Do they not nourish Traytors to the Kingdome in their owne bosome, and hold them so fast in their armes, that no loud outcries for Justice can wring them forth? And now let the whole Kingdome judge, whether they be any longer the power of God, the Apostle describes.
But where then shall we find the power of God, if both King and Parliament have declined from it, and are now found destitute of it?

I answer, I see none of the power of God left in the Kingdome, if it be not to be found in the Army: for certainly the Power of God did first set them up, and since keep them up, and made its residence among them, and fought their battailes, and stormed their Cities and strong holds for them; and as the power of God hath produced them and their workes, so they againe have acted according to Gods power; and I have no where observed of late through the whole Kingdome, any power that hath incouraged and protected and countenanced the good, and cashiered, and punished and revenged upon the evill, as they have done; and therefore the two former powers remaining faint and sinnewlesse, this power only remaines hitherto strong and mighty, and so is like to doe, as long as it remaines the power of God. But the Army of late also hath had its qualmes and Ague fits, and
they have been departing from the power of God, divers of great place in it have become Faithlesse and Heartlesse, and durst not rest on that power alone, for the doing of the workes of God, and so have sought to strengthen themselves in vaine, by the two former empty formes of King and Parliament: yea they have suffered and constrain'd the power of God in and among them (which ought alwaies to be active and operative) to ly still for many moneths together; till the Axel-tree of the Kingdom is crackt quite asunder, and the very foundations of it are tottering, and confusion and ruine like a desperate sicknesse is spreading it selfe through all the members of it, and yet they sit still and do not helpe at all. And this is the great and crying sin of the Army at this time; they say, they are the servants of the Parliament, and they must expect their commands. And are you yet no further? are you yet bewitched and benummed with those Syrens that are among you? can you, honest and valiant men, see the whole Kingdome flaming about your eares, and stand still till you have a Commission to goe quench it? can you heare the outcries of thousands and Millions from all parts of the Kingdome, crying out to you, as the man of Macedonia to Paul, come and helpe us, Oh helpe us, helpe us, from the bondage, oppressions, injustice, delayes, vexations, undoings and grindings to powder of the Ministers of Parliament, Sequestrators, Countrey-Committees, Parliament-Committees, and many such like instruments of woe, who are sucking out the very bloud, and eating out the very hearts and bowells of the Kingdome, and see and heare all this, and ly still at free quarters, and sleep on the best beds, and fare at the best tables, as if this nothing concerned you? know you not yet that Necessity is not to be tyed by any Lawes, nor to be limited by any forms? know you not that to relieve the oppressed, and to break in pieces the oppressors, and what ever else is materially good, is lawfull to be done in case of necessity. If a Troope of your horse march by the high way, and see rogues and robbers spoilng an honest man, will you passe by and refuse to helpe him, till your General give you a Commission for that particular businesse? How then can you answer it to God and the Kingdome, to suffer so many men, and their inheritances, to be oppressed and spoiled, to see Committee-men and Cavaliers tread upon on the neeks of the free borne people of England and to make them bow downe, that they may goe over them, whilest you have power to helpe and succour them, but yet prolong still, and refuse to doe it, because the Parliament hath not commissioned you with any such kind of power: And must the power of God in the Kingdome ask leave of the power of the world and of the Devill, to do justice among men? Must the
power of God be still smothered under a thousand formes, and be kept out of sight, by the customes and traditions of men, that it may not act clearly and above all things among us? That which among many creatures would be a great evill would be a great good among you, to wit, to know your own power: that is, to know how the power of God in the world is power above all power, a free, absolute, universall power, not to be limited by any formes, persons, times or places, but is still to be uppermost in the world. And therfore know, that God hath raised you up for such a time as this is, and if you refuse to help this distressed Nation, whose throat is now become so hoarse with calling for help, that it cannot speak many words more, God will find deliverance for us some other wayes, but you, all of you, shall perish: and you that would not help the afflicted, shall be your selves afflicted, and none shall help you. Yea all the wrongs, oppressions, miseries, woes and evills of this whole Kingdome shall lie upon your heads, whom God had armed with power to remedie them, but you would not.

And therfore bitter shall be the cup of those wise Officers of the Army, who leaving the wisdome of God, have gone down to sense and reason to ask counsell, and to politike men of carnall principles; for their wisdome is their snare, and they have deserted the way of faith. And the Lord be the strength of those men-children, who have appeared as the first fruits of the power of God in the lapsed state of the Army, whose faithfull and powerfull agitations I look upon as some first buddings of Christs Kingdome among us: and increased of God be their faith, who dare undertake, without any humane help, such a work, wherein they are like to find all the power, honour, riches, wisdome, learning, Gentry, Nobility and Royalty of the Kingdome against them; and yet the power of God with them will carrie on his own work against all these, which shall all fall backward before it, as those Officers, who being armed with worldly power to apprehend Christ, fell down backward before Christ the power of God.

And therefore let such godly men, as they have begun in faith, so continue in the same faith, and let all that see the presence and power of God with them, come in unto that power; for what is impossibl • to our power, is possible to his, who worketh all things after the counsell of his own will.
